column1: Severe hypotension can be caused by sudden loss of blood (shock), severe infection, heart attack, or severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis).
This type most often affects older adults, those with high blood pressure, and people with Parkinson disease.

Certain medicines and substances can lead to low blood pressure, including: - Alcohol - Anti-anxiety medicines - Certain antidepressants - Diuretics - Heart medicines, including those used to treat high blood pressure and coronary heart disease - Medicines used for surgery - Painkillers Other causes of low blood pressure include: - Nerve damage from diabetes - Changes in heart rhythm (arrhythmias) - Not drinking enough fluids (dehydration) - Heart failure

The following tests may be done: - Basic metabolic panel - Blood cultures to check for infection - Complete blood count (CBC), including blood differential - ECG - Urinalysis - X-ray of the abdomen - X-ray of the chest

You may be given: - Blood through a needle (IV) - Medicines to increase blood pressure and improve heart strength - Other medicines, such as antibiotics Treatments for low blood pressure after standing up too quickly include: - If medicines are the cause, your provider may change the dosage or switch you to a different drug.
- Your provider may suggest drinking more fluids to treat dehydration.
